title: If there was a universe with no consciousness to observe it, would it even exist? - Quora

response.answer_text: What would such a universe be, in which no seeing, feeling, touching, etc is possible? In what way could that universe be different from a universe which does not exist, other than we, with our conscious imagination can project our own awareness outside of it and just give the remaining abstraction the name of "exists". If we run it the other way, and assume that existence does not require any sort of sensing, feeling, knowing, perceiving, etc then we must ask how and why such things would come to be at all, given that every one of their functions would be mechanically redundant. The universe that exists without consciousness as no plausible way, as far as I can tell, to accidentally develop the possibility of consciousness, let alone the actuality of it. I think that the difficulty in thinking about this philosophical question is that the nature of consciousness is such that it contains limitations which are ultimately a mirage. Our own level of human consciousness is so different from that of other species, that it is easy to think of our particular quality of consciousness as the defining quality, so that plants, bacteria, and even molecules are surely not conscious in a way which is as significant as our own. While this may be true, the question of what it means is another story.  Because consciousness has to do with the framing of experience, perception is not so much a matter of being an accurate or inaccurate model of an external reality, but a way of filtering and shaping experience from the outside in and the inside out. When we see an insect or a rock, we see only the tip of the iceberg which is available to our eyes and skin for inspection. The exterior of the insect is what is seen by through the experience of the cells of our eyes, and the projections of our psyche. It's not that the bug isn't real, it just isn't the same to us in our frame of reference as it is within its local frame of reference, and neither is the universe in general. An insect sees walls as places to walk on, water as something that can be stored in spheres in the middle of a blade of grass, etc. The entire universe could be nothing but nested experiences, even into the subatomic level. As we know, quantum mechanical phenomena are not really conceivable as material objects, but rather as immaterial states of shared tendencies. Isn't that a description of consciousness?

Sorry, but you are pre-supposing that they operate on the same root principles… Where, in Quantum or Classical Physics have you found this root of ‘Consciousness’?? What Consciousness? These relative realities only point to Superposition and Entanglement! Where have you found principles of ABSOLUTE Quantum Consciousness in the Observer?? I haven't found mention of any! Universal Consciousness doesn't even EXIST, according to the Scientist. Now, kindly prevent your mind from tripping over itself, and ponder upon Spirituality for a minute. My friend, you have referred to a Universe, and a Consciousness observing it. Yes? This can only be a Spiritual question. Because this involves Consciousness. Consider this: According to Spiritual Truth, Matter DOESN'T EXIST! Matter and it's Sense-dependent reality is an illusion that Indian Spirituality calls MAYA. The only 'thing' that exists is Conscious Energy. Consciousness. God is Infinite Conscious Energy, according to Indian Spirituality. The Universe/Multiverses are this Infinite Conscious Energy. It's very nature is Consciousness! Now you, the reader of this paragraph, are Conscious Energy. You are The Soul, according to Spirituality. You are merely a subset of the Infinite Conscious Energy. If you cease to observe, or to exist, will that prevent the innate Consciousness of the Universe to exist? No. Because Consciousness will still be observing Consciousness! Consciousness doesn't need eyes or instruments. Consciousness is aware of itself at all times! Still, it is good that the scientifically bent mind is now asking about Consciousness observing Reality. Earlier, people used to only talk about the human's five senses observing Reality. So, yes. Even without our individual consciousness to observe it, the Universe would continue existing quite comfortably. Nice trick question.

Your father's father's father's father is no longer alive. Surprisingly, the universe still exists. All living things are just a bunch of atoms interacting with each other to remain stable. Our conciousness and the ability to think is also a result of this interaction. So, if we really talk in the language of physics, then this interaction is not at all important for the existence of the universe. BUT Quantum Mechanics (or more precisely - Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle) suggests that in some cases, for something to exist in a defined state, we need to measure/observe it. So, if this conclusion is taken to it's extreme limit, it can be said that the moon does not exist if nobody is observing it* (by observing I mean not feeling it's gravity, not seeing it, and not doing anything that tells you about it's presence). The same concept can be applied to the universe. If the lack of consciousness results in our inability to observe things, then the Universe will stop existing (given that no living being in the universe can observe it). *This conclusion is pretty valid at the very small scale (the quantum scale), but it's validity at larger scales is still a topic of debate. Cheers :)

We used not long ago to be the glorious chosen apex of creation, resplendent at the centre of everything, surrounded by our sun, moon and lots of pretty stars spread about by the gods, in tribute to us— a vast panoply we call for good reason the heavens, all created purely for our delight. Over the centuries, we have had to emerge kicking and screaming out of our comfy cocoon into a cold unfriendly universe where we are relegated to a very average little rocky ball in a remote corner of an insignificant galaxy amongst trillions of bigger and better ones. We could even be a dull little bunch of primitive animals ignored by the billions of far mightier intelligences we can never meet, spread across the vastness of a universe we will never be given access to. So, consciousness, according to us, is our tiny minds. Could the universe possibly go on existing without those? Phew! Now I’m not feeling so good. It’s back to the analyst for me. *Omphalocentric. Navel-gazing.

If you take the quotes off of "consciousness", and look at the different meanings the answer isn't that mysterious. So let's do that. If you mean human consciousness (/experience) then broadly speaking no, not at all. The universe is much much older than us, and did not spring into being because some plains apes appeared out of the quantum foam. However, Aspects of what we call reality only exist because of us. Time, for instances, only exists as a perceptual tool for human/animal consciousness, and in that sense if all animals died time wouldn't exist.  If you are willing to accept pan-psychism, the idea that literally everything has an consciousness/experience, then you can make the argument that existence and experience are two sides of the same coin, because if some phenomenon isn't observed/experienced by something else - even just cosmic background radiation, the Higgs Field, etc - then it is indistinguishable from it not happening

There is no good evidence that what we call consciousness is a physically priviledged or special process. People do make claims like this but their evidence is in essence a subjective impression. People believe all sorts of weird stuff based on subjective impressions; humans are imaginative creatures. People also claim that trees are green, but this is “naive realism” assuming that the world is actually identical to our perceptions. Just a little analysis (eg, consider color-blindness) reveals that there is clearly no greenness in trees, the greenness is a trick of presentation that occurs as a result of the way the brain is wired. There is no reason to believe the weird things that people believe about consciousness are any more that tricks of presentation, and a bit of imagination and narrative. The brain is complex and we don’t understand it (that much). Humans struggle with simple things like sudoku; they certainly aren’t going to be capable of analysing the brain itself. So, the workings of our own brain are hidden from ourselves; we have a grossly simplified working representation of what is really going on. Most of the fanciful ideas that is believed about consciousness are errors of naive realism, believing that this representation is that actual workings of the brain. It clearly isn’t, and there is a library of psychological evidence that demonstrates that it isn’t. If a bunch of photons hit an eyeball, a bunch of physical effects occur. Some effects may propagate into the brain. Similarly, a bunch of photons hit a rock a different bunch of physical effects occur. Neither of these events will create the source of the photons.

This question has several drawers: The first: the universe is it virtual (production of the mind) or real (independent of it)? Although the representations of mind about the universe are owners, it is assumed that there is a independent essence of the real. Why is this a good bet? Because if our universe is completely owner of mind, so it strictly says nothing of what is that mind. No external reference. All questions become insoluble in the sense that all the answers are allowed. The second: if there is a independent real, it produced other minds who seem different from our. We can not even « fit » their vision. All we can do is to pool our representations and compare them. Thus we establish a kind of conceptual mold around the real. It is a collectivist process and not a individualist one. The third: if the universe and its representation in our minds are two different things, disappearance of the second don’t stop the first. However the representations of our minds belong to reality. They are the highest part of his organization (we know presently). If all minds disappeared (including non-terrestrial possible), the universe would lose the top layer of its organization. It would become a heap of stupid molecules. Possibly able to rebuild something else... it has been already very creative :-)

It is made up of matter as science tells us. But what is the driving force which makes it a stone and not a plant. This driving force is consciousness. There are different levels of consciousness present. We,humans exhibit the highest level of consciousness but everything,be it living or non living exhibits consciousness. So,to separate consciousness from universe is like talking about yin without yang. You might argue that your view of the universe is based on your consciousness and different people will have different views depending on their levels of consciousness. But the truth is their exists one universal consciousness which governs all sub consciousness if we may call them. This consciousness is independent of whether you perceive it or not. It is the driving force in the universe. If it is not present,the universe will cease to exist.

For a start consciousness is here now, in the universe on this planet earth. Could the universe exist without consciousness? Yes, it could. But because of consciousness we are witnesses to what we call the universe (or that part of it we are capable of observing), the rest is speculation. Without consciousness the universe and all its elements would go on without us. As it did for billions of years before sapient creatures arose on this planet, and as it will long after our world is extinguished when our sun expands and explodes in a few billion years. Now you might hold that we are stardust and from that inception we became conscious beings. So could there be conscious beings out there? Possibly, but unless we are sure of their existence, that also is speculation. We humans are good at speculating possibilities, but just because we can and do speculate does not necessarily give us sufficient grounds to expect our intellectual peregrinations and ratiocinations to be the real deal. Empirically, there is just us floating in space on a tiny planet circumnavigating a star in or very own cosmos, looking out in wonder “Could the universe exist without us,I wonder”.

Yes, of course. Reality, the truth, the universe: none of these things are concerned with human existence (much less, human perception). The universe existed for billions of years before the advent of life. There are some who hold that the moon doesn’t exist unless you look at it. But that’s ridiculous. If a million people look at the moon, not only will they see it, they’ll see it in the same lunar phase — despite not knowing which phase it should be in. If a million rural people were walking outside at midnight during a full moon, they would see their shadow cast by the moon and be able to estimate its position and phase (from its relative brightness) even though they have no idea where the moon should be or which phase it is in. When they turn around and look at the moon, they won’t be surprised that their estimates were pretty reliable.

Sir, to keep things easy and for the sake of clarity, shall we call all that the thought creates as reality? Physical objects which are also a product of thought, though an actuality, that is, though it has an actual physical existence independently of thought to some extent, is equally a part of this reality because to some extent, how one perceives the physical objective world and objects, would depend on one's own background of experiences and perceptions, is it not? A table is a physical object, and therefore has an existence independently outside of thought, and to that extent, it is an actuality. Yet, it is also a product of thought, and to that extent, it is a part of reality too, is it not? If one were to take away, all that is left of this reality, including the psychological self/ the “me or ego”, what remains? When one’s mind is empty, one’s thoughts ceases. In that cessation, there is the cessation of me, the ego, is it not? What is left of my consciousness if the content of the “me” ceases? My content includes, my experiences, feelings, emotions, ideas, opinions, perceptions, prejudices, desires, love, hatred, anger, jealousy, successes, failures, fears, anxieties etc. This is what defines me as a person, is it not? If all this is removed from my consciousness, what am I left with? In other words, if you removed the “I” from your consciousness, what is left? Emptiness, Nothingness, Silence. And in that emptiness there is a tremendous expanding energy. But that source of creation itself can never be a creation for it to be grasped by the mind.Writings of Priyha Kannan

Can the universe exist without hydrogen? Without water? Without dust and other matter? Without light? Each and every component of the Whole is an inevitable part of that Whole. The Whole would not be without its parts and every part is an integral part of the Whole. What seems to be up for debate is whether consciousness is a special part or not. Have you heard of general relativity? Part of it explains that there is no privileged place or time, that everything is relative to everything else. I think that principle holds for all the parts of the Whole; there is no privileged part that is more important, more significant, more real, than any other part. Consciousness merely enables us animals with brains to perceive and evaluate those other parts; it isn’t privileged as a part of that Whole any more than water is because it makes other stuff wet. Consciousness enables us to witness other stuff; it isn’t privileged just because it enables us to witness stuff, it just is. And, it cannot not be, just like everything else in existence.

To say that consciousness is one thing and existence is another, is a gross misunderstanding of the nature of existence.  Knowing how different fields of consciousness interpenetrate and interact should be a goal of science.  Science is still in it's stone age with it's emphasis on a "material" universe separate from consciousness.  The materialist model dominates current thinking and excludes the role of consciousness by limiting it to an epiphenomenon of the human brain.  That is a backward understanding. Yet, the paradigm of materialism is such a dominant or rule set or matrix in human thought, that few see through it.

Well, the materialist assumption is that “things exist independent, apart and outside of cognition”. In the idealist perception of the world however, such would not be true. The existence of the world however prior to the existence of human species or even living species, is nevertheless assumed by science in different fields (astrology, cosmology, geology, etc.). But basically, the question is: what do you mean with ‘existence’? If you mean “knowledge about existence” then sure, only if a conscious observer has gathered knowledge about something existing, only then it can be said to exist. But - on the other hand - if you define existence based on the agreement that things do exist, despite they are not observed and no knowledge exists about their existence or their existential state, then for sure, the universe exists even without someone having awareness about it or knowledge about it.

Yes. Existence precedes observation. Observation is made possible when something already exists. There is no evidence that observation is a cause, or necessary component of, existence. All credible science confirms that existence preceded consciousness. Observation becomes possible after something comes into existence. There is an understandable scientific preference to observe states of existence before acknowledging them but some seem to have confused personal observation with proof. Proof does not require live physical observation. Proof can be derived from logic and secondary observation of results of states of existence. So, yes

Maybe 100 million years before even the first planets had single-celled organisms, and then a long climb from there to entities with a complex enough neural network to be conscious. So… did all that happen? Or did the universe spring into existence in a case of Last Thursdayism, with the first conscious creatures already existing, and photons carefully arranged to look like the universe had been running for 100 million years already, and all the other stuff equally faked up on the spot, right down to that first conscious creature being given fake memories of having been alive before that instant?

Therefore, just as in the cotton-shirt example…wherever the universe is, there consciousness IS. So Consciousness Pervades the entire Universe. Depends who you ask. John Archibald Wheeler postulated an “observer created universe” where, until conscious life appeared, the entire Universe was in a state of quantum indeterminacy. John Archibald Wheeler - Wikipedia When consciousness appeared, this large scale indeterminacy was resolved. That present observations can affect the past was demonstrated in Wheeler's delayed choice experiment - Wikipedia, which was a cosmic-scale double slit experiment, where the two slits are two different paths, due to gravitational lensing, a photon could take in passing a galaxy. The instrumental arrangement the observer chooses affects the results in the same way as in the classic double slit experiment, but in this case, the photon passed the galaxy thousands of years ago.

If there is no conscious mind to perceive the universe, does the universe still exist? Although we cannot know the answer to this question for certain, describing the world is a much simpler task if we assume the existence of an external world—a universe that exists whether we perceive it or not. From one of Bertrand Russell’s popularizations of philosophy, I remember the example of a cat passing behind a pillar. Does the portion of the cat hidden by the pillar de-exist when it is covered up? This bizarre question can be avoided very elegantly and simply by assuming that all of the cat continues to exist whether we perceive it or not. What is more, best scientific evidence suggests that, for most of its existence, the universe was not perceived by humans. Early on, before supernovas created heavy elements, it couldn’t have been perceived by any known thing. Unless you believe that the evidence of the universe’s antiquity was put there to fool us all. The latter hypothesis is not testable and can therefore be dismissed from a serious discussion of the nature of the universe. Even Bishop Berkeley, a champion of the notion that being and being perceived are one and the same, believed in an external world that transcends our human perceptions of it, and preserved his philosophy by invoking a great perceiver of the external world, namely God. tl;dr: Although the objective existence of the universe can’t be proven philosophically, realist accounts of reality (i.e. accounts of reality that assume that the external world exists apart from perception) are simpler than idealist accounts of reality (i.e. accounts of reality that assumes that being perceived and existing are one and the same).

In the beginning, there was the electromagnetic field and the field of space. Their inherent properties caused them to interact until elements, life and finally consciousness appeared. After that, everything continued just the same. What did NOT exist with no observer is all the subjective sensations that we gained through sensory nerves. Hearing, sight, color , smell, taste, and all the sensations we feel through the skin did not exist. So before consciousness arrived, there was an objective, physical universe exactly the same as it would be afterwards, but it was silent, colorless and dark, despite all the enormous disturbances in the atmosphere and the electromagnetic spectrum emitted by stars. Because without sensory organs, those disturbances are as imperceptible as a radio signal passing by without a radio to convert it to sound.

Well, not to itself, and unlike this one we’re in. So that asks the question about whether multiple universes can and do exist, and says something like “If there is a universe with nothing inside it that observes it, can it exist by virtue of some outside observer in a different universe”? And then it took additional billions before any living thing could evolve to the point of consciousness. As one biologist said… “If we generate reality with our minds, what did the universe look like when there was nothing more evolved than a sea-slug?” But lets take this a bit further. Lets say there’s something to this, and by some magical process a conscious mind is necessary to generate “reality”. Where did the conscious mind come from? Did we just pop into existence? Were we “imagined” by some other race of conscious beings? Who imagined them? We very rapidly run into the “infinite regress” problem that besets ideas of God… “Who made God?” The whole thing is silly. We understand the origin and evolution of the universe pretty well. We’re still refining some bits, of course, but give us a bit of time.

Can a physical universe exist without consciousness? What about the universe one thousand years after the Big Bang? Your mistake is to think of consciousness in subjective, mentalistic terms. You do so for the most prosaic of reasons, simply because you encounter your own consciousness—which, again, takes the form of neural activity in your brain—by way of neural connections within your brain in which no perceptual processing takes place, and hence without perceiving it in any way. Since you do not perceive your own consciousness, you do not know what it is, a physical phenomenon of a certain description. But that is irrelevant. Consciousness is one physical phenomenon among indefinitely many, and not a bit more than that. It is time to break free of this subjectivist morass! It is a waste of time. A physical universe can exist without brains, and hence without consciousness.
